ratings.comment: Ai Ethics was a really cool class! I am philosophy major with little background in computer science or coding and I was still able to follow and understand the course really well. The creative project is really fun, my partner and I made a Zine that explained course concepts. I enjoyed the creative freedom and flexibility of the project very much.

Zimmermann taught academic principles of fairness, ethics, and the philosophy of AI in an interesting and engaging way for people coming from STEM heavy or non-philosophy backgrounds. She is exceptionally busy but her class felt like it was neatly prepared each day. For anyone interested in AI/ML or technology policy her classes are recommended.

Philosophy 543 with Professor Zimmerman offers a refreshing change of pace. Weekly discussions feature student presentations followed by peer reviews and group dialogue. As a Computer Sciences major, I did not feel out of place. Quite the opposite in fact–it was the most fun I've had in a while. I highly recommend!

Professor Zimmermann is is very well spoken and her lectures are easy to follow. Her slides contain just enough information, but attendance is still necessary considering how much of this class is built on in-class discussion. There are plenty of opportunities to earn points and Prof. Z is flexible with scoring and assignments.

Professor Zimmermann's lectures for Philos541 were well suited to support my learning as we engaged in a variety of activities (debates, outlines, small-group discussion). Constructive and supportive feedback was given on essays to help improve writing. Overall, I enjoyed all of the topics we covered, so I would definitely recommend!

Professor Zimmerman is an incredibly knowledgable teacher who made Philos341 interesting and relatable. She teaches topics that could find to be somewhat dry in a way that makes this feel important, interesting, and crucial for the progression of modern day policy questions. This class has only 1 paper and two exams so I highly recommend taking it.

Philos 341 with Professor Zimmerman was a great experience. Her lectures were very informative and captivating. Class discussions and group projects were insightful and very helpful in preparing for the exams. Despite the numerous reading assignments, the material was mostly introductory level, so the workload was manageable.

Prof Zimmermann is very knowledgeable in her field! The way she leads the class allows students to build their own emphasis on topics that they find interesting. I had so much fun and found the discussions very interesting. The syllabus can feel intense but it's really not that much work!

Professor Zimmerman makes 541 encompassing of several different topics in philosophy that are interesting to cover, and the assignments are also not meant to trick but to help the student learn. Discussion is most of the class period, and you get out what you put in there. Overall, would highly recommend this class.

Professor Zimmermann was an amazing professor! I thoroughly enjoyed her class, and even though it heavily depended on class conversations, she created a conversation structure that truly benefits the students. While the readings can be dense at times, she makes the class fun and interesting even for students who aren't majoring in philosophy.

She is an excellent lecturer that facilitates great discussion. 541 is designed to give agency to the students in leading the breakdown and discussion of the material with Professor Zimmermann serving as a backbone for connecting ideas between students, working through complex topics, and introducing thought-provoking questions. Would 100% retake.

Professor Zimmerman is a outstanding teacher, incredibly knowledgeable with a fantastic course structure. She is very skilled in letting students lead discussions while keeping the focus on main points. Despite the heavy amount of readings and content, she is a fair grader and one of the best teachers I have had.

Professor Zimmermann is well-versed in the topics taught in the class, but she goes through a lot of information very quickly. There is an expectation to participate in lecture, which can feel daunting for students who are not used to speaking in front of large groups. The majority of the grades (besides midterms and the final) are group work.

She was very knowledgable and wears cool outfits but thats about all she does well. Does not allow questions in class and reads off the slides, your enjoyment in this class depends on the quality of your TA.

Lectures are dry and her slides carry a lot of information that make it hard to follow. Lectures include regular content, debates, and presentations. She is fairly clear but her expectations are inconcistent at times. She did make adjusments to exam format due to the class being a lot of inexperienced Philos takers. She was okay, not a fan.

Prof Zimmermann is clearly very knowledgeable in her field of study, but as a teacher, this course was terrible. Her lectures, which occurred three times per week, were dry, rambly, and difficult to follow. The exams were all hand-written, in-class and graded hard.

This is one of those classes where it could be very enjoyable if the professor was good. She is not. Prepare to do 20+ page difficult readings every other day. Only graded on 3 exams. Her slides are full paragraphs and she skips through them within seconds so it's either try to take notes or process what she's saying. Rude and not understanding.
